Code and stacktrace posted below. Thanks

text: that would need to read m = next((x for x in markets if x['marketId'] == b.market_id) , None)

text: assuming marketId is the key in the markets dict ... you can log out the markets dict

elements.text: assuming marketId is the key in the markets dict ... you can log out the markets dict

text: otherwise don't use lightweight=True to get the object wrappers

elements.text: otherwise don't use lightweight=True to get the object wrappers

text: then you can use x.market_id

text: Originally the library just used to return the raw dictionaries hence the name, I then changed it in v1 to return objects, people got angry so we added lightweight mode

text: for the "regular" api client, the passive GET/POST calls, it's not *quite* as relevant (for regular usage), but for the streaming area, there's a huge difference between the regular "object" return, and the "raw" mode, what betfair gives over the streaming service

elements.text: for the "regular" api client, the passive GET/POST calls, it's not
quite
as relevant (for regular usage), but for the streaming area, there's a huge difference between the regular "object" return, and the "raw" mode, what betfair gives over the streaming service

text: as with all things, it's a trade-off, if you're *only* looking for 1, 2 things from your market calls "competition" or "event-name", or something, then "lightweight" is probably better, maybe, but if you're getting nearly all the data from the object, and running through all the runners of each of the markets, etc. it's probably better for you to have them not-lightweight, and be real objects

elements.text: as with all things, it's a trade-off, if you're
